greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle of q-Bell number coefficients, read by rows that form polynomials in q, giving the eigensequence for the triangle of q-binomial coefficients.
comment: Row n evaluated at sample values of q are as follows:
R_n(q=-1) = A080107(n) (fixed points of permutation of SetPartitions);
link: Alois P. Heinz, Rows n = 0..50, flattened
formula: T(n,0) = 2^(n-1) for n>0. G.f. of row n is a polynomial in q, B_q(n), that is generated by the recurrence: B_q(n) = Sum_{j=0..n-1} B_q(j) * C_q(n-1,j) for n>0, with B_q(0)=1. The q-binomial coefficient (also called Gaussian binomial coefficient) is given by: C_q(n,k) = [Product_{i=n-k+1..n} (1-q^i)]/[Product_{j=1..k} (1-q^j)].
Sum_{k>0} k * T(n,k) = A264082(n). - _Alois P. Heinz_, Apr 03 2016
example: Row g.f.s B_q(n) are polynomials in q generated by:
B_q(n) = Sum_{j=0..n-1} B_q(j) * C_q(n-1,j) for n>0 with B_q(0)=1
where the triangle of q-binomial coefficients C_q(n,k) begins:
The initial q-Bell coefficients in B_q(n) are:
Number of terms in row n is given by A125811, which starts:
mathematica: QB[n_, q_] := QB[n, q] = Sum[QB[j, q] QBinomial[n-1, j, q], {j, 0, n-1}] // FunctionExpand // Simplify; QB[0, q_]=1; QB[1, q_]=1; Table[ CoefficientList[QB[n, q], q], {n, 0, 9}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Feb 29 2016 *)
program: /* q-Bell numbers = eigensequence of q-binomial triangle: */
results.author: _Paul D. Hanna_, Dec 10 2006
